(Whole device max power draw = 25W
APU TDP = 4 - 15W)
5200 mAh | platform = | currentfw = | service = [[Steam (service)|Steam]] | dimensions = {{convert|298|x|117|x|49|mm|in|abbr=on}} | weight = {{convert|669|g|lb}} | topgame = | compatibility = | predecessor = | successor = | related = | website = {{URL|https://www.steamdeck.com/}} }} The '''Steam Deck''' is a [[Handheld PC|handheld]] [[gaming computer]] developed by [[Valve Corporation|Valve]] and released on February 25, 2022. The device uses Valve's [[Linux distribution]] [[SteamOS]], which incorporates the namesake [[Steam (service)|Steam]] storefront. SteamOS uses Valve's [[Proton (software)|Proton]] [[compatibility layer]], allowing users to run [[Windows]] applications and games. In addition to handheld use, the Steam Deck can be connected to a [[TV]] or [[computer monitor|monitor]] through a [[docking station]] and be used like a [[desktop computer]] or [[home video game console]]. In desktop mode, users are allowed to install [[Linux]]-based third-party applications. ==History== Valve's [[Steam Machine (hardware platform)|Steam Machine]] series of gaming computers using [[Linux]]-derived [[SteamOS]] was introduced in 2015, which worked their way into the conception of the Steam Deck. Valve quietly pulled back on it by April 2018, but stated they remained committed to providing some type of open-hardware platform.{{Cite web |last=Phillips |first=Tom |date=April 4, 2018 |title='It's true Steam Machines aren't exactly flying off the shelves' |url=https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2018-04-04-its-true-steam-machines-arent-exactly-flying-off-the-shelves |access-date=April 4, 2018 |website=[[Eurogamer]]}} Steam Deck designer Scott Dalton said "there was always kind of this classic [[chicken and egg problem]] with the Steam Machine", as it required the adoption of Linux by both gamers and game developers to reach a critical interest in the machines to draw manufacturers in making them.{{Cite web |last=Marks |first=Tom |date=July 30, 2021 |title=Valve Explains How The Failure of Steam Machines Helped Build The Steam Deck |url=https://www.ign.com/articles/steam-deck-valve-explains-how-it-learned-from-past-mistakes |access-date=July 30, 2021 |website=[[IGN]]}} The lack of Linux game availability during the lifetime of Steam Machines led Valve to invest development into [[Proton (software)|Proton]], a Linux compatibility layer to allow Windows–based games to be run on Linux without modification. Some of the early prototypes of Valve's [[Steam Controller]], also released in 2015, included a small LCD screen within the middle of the controller which could be programmed as a second screen alongside the game that the user was playing. One idea from this prototype was to include the [[Steam Link]], a device capable of streaming game content from a computer running Steam to a different monitor, here routing that output to the small LCD on the controller. This was later considered by Valve a very early concept behind the Steam Deck. Further, their experience with trying to convince other manufacturers to produce Steam Machines led Valve to realize that it was better to develop all their hardware internally. Dalton said, "More and more it just became kind of clear, the more of this we are doing internally, the more we can kind of make a complete package." Rumors that Valve was working on a portable gaming unit had emerged in May 2021, based on updates made within the Steam code pointing towards a new "SteamPal" device, and comments made by Gabe Newell related to Valve developing games for consoles. ''[[Ars Technica]]'' had been able to confirm that new hardware was in development at Valve.{{Cite web |last=Mackovech |first=Sam |date=May 25, 2021 |title=Exclusive: Valve is making a Switch-like portable gaming PC |url=https://arstechnica.com/gaming/2021/05/exclusive-valve-is-making-a-switch-like-portable-gaming-pc/ |access-date=July 15, 2021 |website=[[Ars Technica]]}} Valve revealed the Steam Deck on July 15, 2021. The Deck, existing in three different models based on internal storage options, was shipped starting in February 2022 in North America and Europe, with other regions to follow throughout the year.{{Cite web |last=Peters |first=Jay |date=July 15, 2021 |title=Valve's gaming handheld is called the Steam Deck and it's shipping in December |url=https://www.theverge.com/2021/7/15/22578783/valve-steam-deck-gaming-handheld-pc |access-date=July 15, 2021 |website=[[The Verge]]}}{{Cite web |last=Peters |first=Jay |date=November 10, 2021 |title=Steam Deck launch delayed by two months |url=https://www.theverge.com/2021/11/10/22774888/steam-deck-delayed-two-months-february-2022-launch-shipping |access-date=November 10, 2021 |website=[[The Verge]]}} However, due to its popularity, some pre-order purchasers were informed that later shipments of the 64 GB model and 256 GB NVMe models would be in Q2 2022 and the 512 GB NVMe model by Q3 2022.{{Cite web |last=Yin-Poole |first=Wesley |date=July 17, 2021 |title=Steam Deck expected order availability now Q1 2022 (64GB) and Q2 2022 (256GB/512GB) |url=https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2021-07-17-steam-deck-expected-order-availability-now-q1-2022-64gb-or-q2-2022-256gb-512gb |access-date=July 17, 2021 |website=[[Eurogamer]]}} Valve informed pre-purchasers in November 2021 that due to the [[2020-present global chip shortage|ongoing global chip shortage]], the device would fail to ship by December and instead would ship in February 2022, retaining the same order for delivery based on pre-order placement. Valve's CEO, [[Gabe Newell]], said of the Steam Deck's approach, "As a gamer, this is a product I've always wanted. And as a game developer, it's the mobile device I've always wanted for our partners."{{Cite web |last=Schreier |first=Jason |date=July 15, 2021 |title=Nintendo Switch Gets New Rival With Valve's Portable Steam Console |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-07-15/nintendo-switch-gets-new-rival-with-valve-s-portable-console |access-date=July 16, 2021 |website=[[Bloomberg News]]}} According to Newell, they wanted to be "very aggressive" on the release and pricing strategy as they considered the mobile market as their primary competitor for the Deck. However, their focus was on the unit's performance; Newell stated, "But the first thing was the performance and the experience, [that] was the biggest and most fundamental constraint that was driving this."{{Cite web |last=Bailey |first=Kat |date=July 15, 2021 |title=Gabe Newell: Hitting Steam Deck Price Was 'Painful' but 'Critical' |url=https://www.ign.com/articles/steam-deck-price-valve-gabe-newell-400-dollars-painful-but-critical |access-date=July 15, 2021 |website=[[IGN]]}} Newell recognized that the base pricing was somewhat lower than expected and "painful", but necessary to meet the expectation of gamers that would want the Deck. Newell continued that he believed this was a new product category of personal computer hardware that Valve and other computer manufacturers would continue to participate in if the Steam Deck proved successful, and thus it was necessary to keep the unit's price point reasonable to demonstrate viability.{{Cite web |last=Chalk |first=Andy |date=July 15, 2021 |title=Gabe Newell expects Steam Deck to sell 'millions of units' but the pricing was 'painful' to pick |url=https://www.pcgamer.com/gabe-newell-expects-steam-deck-to-sell-millions-of-units-but-the-pricing-was-painful-to-pick/ |access-date=July 15, 2021 |website=[[PC Gamer]]}} The openness of the system was also a key feature according to Newell, as that is a defining "superpower" of the personal computer space over typical console systems. Newell did not want to have any limitations on what the end user could do with the hardware, such as installing alternate non-Steam software on it.{{Cite web |last=Skrebeles |first=Joe |date=July 28, 2021 |title=Gabe Newell Pushes Back Against Closed Platforms, Says Openness is 'PC's Superpower' |url=https://www.ign.com/articles/steam-deck-openness-superpower-closed-platforms-gabe-newell |access-date=July 29, 2021 |website=[[IGN]]}} Pre-orders for the Steam Deck were opened a day after its announcement. Pre-orders were limited to those with [[Steam (service)|Steam]] accounts opened before June 2021, to prevent resellers from depleting stock and making the device more difficult to purchase. First-day pre-order reservations through the Steam storefront briefly crashed the servers due to the demand. By September 2021, [[Game development kit|development kits]] for the Steam Deck were shipping to developers.{{Cite web |last=Campbell |first=Ian Carlos |date=September 14, 2021 |title=Valve's Steam Deck is now real enough to send to developers |url=https://www.theverge.com/2021/9/14/22673732/valve-steam-deck-dev-kits-shipping |access-date=September 14, 2021 |website=[[The Verge]]}} The device was released on February 25, 2022.{{Cite web |last=Dawe |first=Liam |date=2022-02-25 |title=The Steam Deck has released, here's my initial review |url=https://www.gamingonlinux.com/2022/02/steam-deck-initial-review/ |access-date=2022-02-25 |website=GamingOnLinux |language=en}}{{Cite web |last=Larabel |first=Michael |date=2022-02-25 |title=For Linux Enthusiasts Especially, The Steam Deck Is An Incredible & Fun Device |url=https://www.phoronix.com/scan.php?page=article&item=steam-deck-steamos-linux |access-date=2022-02-25 |website=[[Phoronix]] |language=en}} For the planned release in Asian regions, Valve worked with Komodo to help with local production, localization, and distribution support.{{Cite web |title=Steam Deck Comes to Japan, South Korea, Taiwan & Hong Kong (SteamDeck booklet) |url=http://media.steampowered.com/apps/valve/2022/steamDeck_booklet_EN.pdf |website=[[Steam (service)|Steam]]}} By June 2022, Valve stated they were able to double the number of Steam Decks shipping out each week, helping to meet the initial reservations,{{Cite web |last=Jimenez |first=Jorge |date=June 27, 2022 |title=Valve is ramping up Steam Deck production as Q3 reservation emails go out this week |url=https://www.pcgamer.com/steam-decks-production-has-outperformed-valve-estimates-so-its-shipping-units-out-early/ |access-date=October 6, 2022 |website=[[PC Gamer]]}} and by August 2022, Valve's production was outpacing expectations, allowing them to send out Steam Decks to consumers that were originally anticipated to ship in the final quarter of the year.{{Cite web |last=Jimenez |first=Jorge |date=August 27, 2022 |title=Steam Deck's 'production has outperformed' Valve estimates, so it's shipping units out early |url=https://www.pcgamer.com/steam-decks-production-has-outperformed-valve-estimates-so-its-shipping-units-out-early/ |access-date=October 6, 2022 |website=[[PC Gamer]]}} Valve was able to fulfill all reservations by October 2022, opening the Steam Deck to purchase without reservation, though Valve tentatively will return to a reservation system should demand be too high.{{Cite web |last=Clark |first=Mitchell |date=2022-10-06 |title=The Steam Deck is now available with no reservations required (mostly) |url=https://www.theverge.com/2022/10/6/23391396/steam-deck-available-buy-now-reservations |access-date=2022-10-06 |website=[[The Verge]] |language=en-US}} As of December 2022, Valve is pursuing improvements on the current Steam Deck design, including an audio mixer, per-game "power profiles", and some other performance improvements, as well as evaluating a second generation Steam Deck. Valve is also considering bringing some of the Steam Deck technology into a new Steam Controller 2.{{Cite web |last=Hollister |first=Sean |date=December 15, 2022 |title=Valve answers our burning Steam Deck questions — including a possible Steam Controller 2 |url=https://www.theverge.com/23499215/valve-steam-deck-interview-late-2022 |access-date=December 20, 2022 |website=[[The Verge]]}} ==Hardware== The Steam Deck includes a custom [[AMD APU]] based on their [[Zen 2]] and [[RDNA 2]] architectures, named Aerith, after the ''[[Final Fantasy VII]]'' character [[Aerith Gainsborough]].{{Cite web |last=Hollister |first=Sean |date=November 12, 2021 |title=Steam Deck: Five big things we learned from Valve's developer summit |url=https://www.theverge.com/22779252/steam-deck-things-we-learned-from-valve-developer-summit |access-date=November 12, 2021 |website=[[The Verge]]}} The CPU runs a four-core/eight-thread unit and the GPU runs on eight [[compute unit]]s with a total estimated performance of 1.6 TFLOPS. Both the CPU and GPU use variable timing frequencies, with the CPU running between 2.4 and 3.5 GHz and the GPU between 1.0 and 1.6 GHz based on current processor needs. Valve stated that the CPU has comparable performance to [[Ryzen 3000]] desktop computer processors and the GPU performance to the [[Radeon RX 6000 series]]. The Deck includes 16 GB of [[LPDDR5]] [[RAM]] in a quad-channel configuration, with a total bandwidth of 88 GB/s.{{Cite web |last=Loeffler |first=John |date=July 21, 2021 |title=Steam Deck gets a spec update, and it's good news for gamers |url=https://www.techradar.com/news/steam-deck-gets-a-spec-update-and-its-good-news-for-gamers |access-date=July 22, 2021 |website=[[TechRadar]]}} [[File:Close view of Steam Deck D-pad and analogue stick (cropped).jpg|thumb|left|Close view of the Steam Deck directional pad, thumbstick, and portion of trackpad]] The Deck's main unit is designed for handheld use. It includes a {{convert|7|in|mm|adj=on}} touchscreen [[LCD]] display with a 1280×800 pixel resolution with a fixed 60 Hz [[refresh rate]]; games are configured to use [[Screen tearing#Vertical synchronization|vertical synchronization]] where possible. The unit's input set features two thumbsticks, a directional pad, ABXY buttons, two shoulder buttons on each side of the unit, four additional buttons on the rear of the unit, as well as two trackpads under each thumbstick.{{Cite web |last=Moore |first=Bo |date=July 15, 2021 |title=Steam Deck: The First Hands-On With Valve's Handheld Gaming PC |url=https://www.ign.com/articles/steam-deck-hands-on-impressions-details-valve-handheld-gaming-pc |access-date=July 15, 2021 |website=[[IGN]]}} The thumbsticks and trackpads use [[capacitive sensing]], and the unit further includes a [[gyroscope]] to allow for more specialized controls on the handheld mode. The unit also includes [[Haptic technology|haptic feedback]]. The Deck supports [[Bluetooth]] connectivity for input devices, including common game controllers, and includes integrated [[WiFi]] network support to meet [[IEEE 802.11]]a/b/g/n/ac standards,{{Cite web |last=Phillips |first=Tom |date=July 15, 2021 |title=Valve announces Steam Deck, a £349 handheld PC |url=https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2021-07-15-valve-announces-steam-deck-a-gbp349-handheld-pc |access-date=July 15, 2021 |website=[[Eurogamer]]}}{{Cite web |last=McCaffery |first=Ryan |date=July 15, 2021 |title=Steam Deck FAQ: Valve Answers the Biggest Questions |url=https://www.ign.com/articles/steam-deck-valve-faq-big-questions-answered |access-date=July 15, 2021 |website=[[IGN]]}} stereo sound out via a [[digital signal processor]], an integrated microphone and a headphone jack, a 40 watt-hour battery, which Valve estimates that for "lighter use cases like game streaming, smaller 2D games, or web browsing" can last between seven and eight hours. Valve also estimated that by keeping frame rates to around 30 [[frames per second]] (FPS) more intensive games such as ''[[Portal 2]]'' could be played for five to six hours. The system's software includes an optional FPS limiter that balance a game's performance to optimize battery life.{{Cite web |last=Hollister |first=Sean |date=July 25, 2021 |title=The Steam Deck has an 'optional built-in FPS limiter' for better battery life |url=https://www.theverge.com/2021/7/25/22593079/valve-steam-deck-fps-limiter-target-performance-battery-life |access-date=July 25, 2021 |website=[[The Verge]]}} At release, Steam Decks were only manufactured in a black casing to reduce the complexity of production, though Valve stated that they have considered introducing other case colors or themes in the future.{{Cite web |last=Wickens |first=Katie |date=August 6, 2021 |title=Valve says there is 'tons of opportunity' around different colours for future Steam Decks |url=https://www.pcgamer.com/valve-steam-deck-colour-scheme-discussions-interview-coomer/ |access-date=August 6, 2021 |website=[[PC Gamer]]}} Valve partnered with [[iFixit]] to provide replacement parts for users.{{Cite web |last=Fenlon |first=Wes |date=February 15, 2022 |title=Valve is partnering with iFixit to sell Steam Deck replacement parts |url=https://www.pcgamer.com/valve-is-partnering-with-ifixit-to-sell-steam-deck-replacement-parts/ |access-date=February 15, 2022 |website=[[PC Gamer]]}} The unit shipped in three models based on internal storage options. The base model includes a 64 GB [[eMMC]] internal storage unit, running over [[PCI Express 2.0|PCI Express 2.0 x1]]. A mid-tier model includes 256 GB of storage through an [[NVMe]] SSD device, while the high-end unit includes a 512 GB NVMe SSD storage unit, with the latter two both shipping with drives that run [[PCI Express 3.0|PCI Express 3.0 x4]]. All 3 [[Stock keeping unit|SKUs]] utilize the same [[M.2]] 2230 interface for internal storage. Valve stated that the built-in storage is not meant to be replaceable by end-users, though can be replaced as necessary for repair.{{Cite web |last=Moore |first=Bo |date=July 21, 2021 |title=Steam Deck SSD is Upgradeable, But It Won't Be Easy |url=https://www.ign.com/articles/steam-deck-ssd-upgradeable-valve |access-date=July 21, 2021 |website=[[IGN]]}} Additional storage space is available through a [[microSD]] card slot, which also supports [[microSDXC]] and [[microSDHC]] formats. As Valve considered options for bringing a handheld device to market, they set a priority that the device had to be able to play nearly the entirety of the Steam game catalogue, and rejected possible hardware that moved away from the standard [[x86]]-based processing structure that would have been easier to implement in handheld form but would have limited what games would be available. Only through recent discussions with AMD and their current product lines was Valve able to identify a technical approach that would meet the goal of a handheld device capable of playing all Steam games without overtaxing the processor unit.{{Cite web |last=Castle |first=Katherine |date=August 24, 2021 |title=The Steam Deck interview: Valve's designers on all things hardware, software, and knowing when to stop |url=https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/the-steam-deck-interview-valves-designers-on-all-things-hardware-software-and-knowing-when-to-stop |access-date=August 24, 2021 |website=[[Rock Paper Shotgun]]}} The developers considered the Steam Deck to be [[future-proof]]. While the specifications are modest compared to high-end gaming computers, they felt that the performance was at a good place that would be acceptable for many years, while still looking at newer software improvements, such as the addition of AMD's [[FidelityFX Super Resolution]] (FSR).{{Cite web |last=Purslow |first=Matt |date=July 29, 2021 |title=Valve Says Steam Deck Is Future Proof, But Could Add New Generations |url=https://www.ign.com/articles/valve-steam-deck-future-proof-new-generations |access-date=July 29, 2021 |website=[[IGN]]}} Though they do not have any current designs for a successor, Valve stated that there would likely be future iterations of the hardware in years to come, but the company expects the timing of releases to depend on the current state of processor technology and handheld device limitations rather than a regular upgrade cycle. === Docking Station === A dock unit was released on October 6, 2022.{{Cite web |last=Peters |first=Jay |date=October 6, 2022 |title=Valve's Steam Deck Dock is now available to order |url=https://www.theverge.com/2022/10/6/23391245/valve-steam-deck-dock-reservation-cost-price |website=[[The Verge]]}} The dock unit can be connected to an external power source to power the Deck, and to an external monitor via either [[HDMI]] or [[DisplayPort]] protocols to route output from the Deck to that monitor. Though limited by the processor speed, the display output from the Deck via the dock can reach as high as [[8k resolution]] at 60 Hz or [[4k resolution]] at 120 Hz; this resolution boost can also be achieved by attaching the Deck directly through a USB to HDMI adapter without the use of the docking station. There is no other change in performance of the Steam Deck whether docked or when used in portable mode.{{Cite web |last=Ridley |first=Jacob |date=August 8, 2021 |title=The Steam Deck will not boost performance while docked |url=https://www.pcgamer.com/uk/steam-deck-dock-performance/ |access-date=August 8, 2021 |website=[[PC Gamer]]}} The dock also supports [[Ethernet]] network connectivity and support for [[USB]] connections for controllers or other input devices. The Deck can also work with any third-party docking station that supports similar types of interfacing for portable devices. [[Graphics processing unit#External GPU (eGPU)|External GPUs]] are not officially supported,{{Cite web |date=2022-02-28 |title=Steam Deck :: FAQ |url=https://www.steamdeck.com/en/faq |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220228070503/https://www.steamdeck.com/en/faq |archive-date=28 February 2022 |access-date=2022-02-28}} although testing via the M2 slot has demonstrated that eGPUs are capable of running when connected to the Deck.{{Cite web |last=Hollister |first=Sean |date=April 13, 2022 |title=Someone plugged an entire 4K desktop graphics card into the Steam Deck |url=https://www.theverge.com/2022/4/13/23023839/valve-steam-deck-egpu-external-amd-rx-6900-xt-4k-eta-prime |website=[[The Verge]]}} ==Software== [[File:SteamOS 3.0 neofetch screenshot.png|thumb|right|Screenshot of [[Neofetch]] showing Steam Deck specification]] Steam Deck runs [[SteamOS]] version 3, based on the [[Arch Linux]] operating system. While SteamOS had been previously developed for Steam Machines using [[Debian]] Linux, Valve stated that they wanted to use a [[Rolling release|rolling upgrade]] approach for the Deck's system software, a function Debian was not designed for but was a feature of Arch Linux.{{Cite web |last=Dexter |first=Alan |date=August 9, 2021 |title=This is why Valve is switching from Debian to Arch for Steam Deck's Linux OS |url=https://www.pcgamer.com/this-is-why-valve-is-switching-from-debian-to-arch-for-steam-decks-linux-os/ |access-date=August 9, 2021 |website=[[PC Gamer]]}} An [[application programming interface]] (API) specific for the Steam Deck is available to game developers, allowing a game to specify certain settings if it is being run on a Steam Deck compared to a normal computer.{{Cite web |last=Ridley |first=Jacob |date=August 6, 2021 |title=Valve is creating a Steam Deck API for devs to quickly optimise games |url=https://www.pcgamer.com/valve-steam-deck-api-optimisation/ |access-date=August 6, 2021 |website=[[PC Gamer]]}} Within the Steam storefront, developers can populate a special file depot for their game with lower-resolution textures and other reduced elements to allow their game to perform better on the Steam Deck; Steam automatically detects and downloads the appropriate files for the system (whether on a computer or Steam Deck) when the user installs the game. The Deck displays compatible games from the Steam storefront. Games developed for Linux run natively. The SteamOS software includes support for [[Proton (software)|Proton]], a compatibility layer that allows games developed for [[Windows]] to be played on the Linux-based SteamOS.{{Cite web |last=Duckett |first=Chris |date=July 16, 2021 |title=Steam Deck is an AMD-powered handheld PC from Valve that runs KDE on Arch Linux |url=https://www.zdnet.com/article/steam-deck-is-an-amd-powered-handheld-pc-from-valve-that-runs-kde-on-arch-linux/ |access-date=July 16, 2021 |website=[[ZDNet]]}} According to ProtonDB, a community-run database that compiles information on game compatibility of Steam games within Linux using Proton, several of Steam's more popular game releases were not yet compatible with Proton primarily due to anti-circumvention and [[anti-cheat]] controls or [[digital rights management]] (DRM). Valve stated they were working with vendors of these middleware solutions to improve Proton support while also encouraging Linux-specific versions to be developed.{{Cite web |last=Clayton |first=Natalie |date=July 16, 2021 |title=Unless something changes, Steam Deck won't run Destiny, Apex, PUBG or Siege |url=https://www.pcgamer.com/unless-something-changes-steam-deck-wont-run-destiny-apex-pubg-or-siege/ |access-date=July 16, 2021 |website=[[PC Gamer]]}} [[Epic Games]]' Easy Anti-Cheat, one of the more popular anti-cheat options for developers, was made available for MacOS and Linux systems in September 2021, which Epic stated that developers could easily transition for the Proton layer.{{Cite web |last=Hollister |first=Sean |date=September 23, 2021 |title=One of the Steam Deck's biggest hurdles just disappeared: EAC has come to Linux |url=https://www.theverge.com/2021/9/23/22690670/epic-eac-anti-cheat-linux-valve-steam-deck-support-games |access-date=September 23, 2021 |website=[[The Verge]]}} Valve worked with Epic over the end of 2021 to make the transition of Easy Anti-Cheat to Proton simple for developers.{{Cite web |last=Blake |first=Vikki |date=January 22, 2022 |title=Steam Deck can now support games with Easy Anti-Cheat |url=https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2022-01-22-steam-deck-can-now-support-games-with-easy-anti-cheat |access-date=January 22, 2022 |website=[[Eurogamer]]}} Another popular anti-cheat solution, [[BattlEye]], also affirmed their software was ready to work with the Proton layer and only required developers to opt-in to enable it.{{Cite web |last=Chalk |first=Andy |date=2021-09-25 |title=BattlEye anti-cheat confirms Steam Deck support |url=https://www.pcgamer.com/battleye-anti-cheat-confirms-steam-deck-support/ |access-date=2021-09-25 |website=[[PC Gamer]]}} Valve stated that in testing games otherwise currently available on Linux or compatible with the Proton layer, they had yet to find a game that failed to meet a minimum 30 frames-per-second performance on the handheld, a performance metric comparable to the consoles of the [[eighth generation of video game consoles|eighth generation]].{{Cite web |last=Weatherbed |first=Jess |date=July 23, 2021 |title=Valve claims the Steam Deck can handle any game you throw at it, including AAAs |url=https://www.techradar.com/news/valve-claims-the-steam-deck-can-handle-any-game-you-throw-at-it-including-aaas |access-date=July 23, 2021 |website=[[TechRadar]]}} The Proton layer includes support for AMD's upscaling technology [[FidelityFX Super Resolution]] (FSR); while Proton also supports Nvidia's [[DLSS]] upscaling solution, this was not included in the Deck.{{Cite web |last=Willetts |first=Samuel |date=November 25, 2021 |title=Proton now officially supports Nvidia DLSS, but it won't come to Valve's Steam Deck |url=https://www.pcgamesn.com/steam-deck/proton-dlss-support |access-date=November 25, 2021 |website=[[PCGamesN]]}} Due to potential confusion on game compatibility, Valve introduced a process in October 2021 by which they brought in additional staff to review games on Steam in order to make sure a game is fully playable on the Steam Deck. Games that are confirmed to be compatible with the Steam Deck, including those with Proton and any middleware DRM solutions, that by default meet minimum performance specifications, are marked as "Verified". Games that may require some user tinkering with settings, such as having to use a system control to bring up the on-screen keyboard, are tagged as "Playable". Another category, "Unsupported", are games that Valve has tested to not be fully compatible with the Steam Deck, such as VR games or games using Windows-specific [[codec]]s that have not yet been made compatible with Proton. These ratings are to change over time as both the Steam Deck software improves as well as updates made by developers to games to improve compatibility with the Steam Deck software.{{Cite web |last=Archer |first=James |date=October 18, 2021 |title=Exclusive: Here's how you'll know which games will run on Valve's Steam Deck |url=https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/steam-deck-compatibility-interview |access-date=October 18, 2021 |website=[[Rock Paper Shotgun]]}}{{Cite web |last=Orland |first=Kyle |date=January 21, 2022 |title=Here's why some games aren't "verified" for Steam Deck compatibility |url=https://arstechnica.com/gaming/2022/01/heres-why-some-games-arent-verified-for-steam-deck-compatibility/ |access-date=January 21, 2022 |website=[[Ars Technica]]}} [[File:Steam Deck Steam UI.jpg|thumb|left|The library page for the Steam client used on the Steam Deck. The additional icons in the bottom right of the top left game image indicate the game is Steam Deck verified.]] The Steam client on the Deck features a revised interface and functions different from the desktop client. Unlike Steam's Big Picture mode which was designed for use on television screens, which was treated as a separate software branch within Valve, the Deck version of the Steam client stays consistent with the desktop version, adding functions and interface elements to make navigating through Steam easier with controller input, and indicators typical for portable systems such as battery life and wireless connectivity. Valve replaced the previous Big Picture mode in Steam with one based on the Steam Deck user interface in February 2023.{{Cite web |last=Prescott |first=Shaun |date=July 20, 2021 |title=Steam's Big Picture mode will be replaced by Steam Deck's UI |url=https://www.pcgamer.com/steams-big-picture-mode-will-be-replaced-by-steam-decks-ui/ |access-date=July 20, 2021 |website=[[PC Gamer]]}}{{Cite web |last=Wales |first=Matt |date=February 1, 2023 |title=Steam Big Picture's Steam-Deck-inspired UI overhaul finally gets its full release |url=https://www.eurogamer.net/steam-big-pictures-steam-deck-inspired-ui-overhaul-finally-gets-its-full-release |access-date=February 1, 2023 |website=[[Eurogamer]]}} The version of Steam on the Deck otherwise supports all other functions of Steam, including user profiles and friends lists, access to game communities, cloud saving, Steam Workshop support, and the Remote Play feature.{{Cite web |last=Marshall |first=Cass |date=July 15, 2021 |title=The cheapest Steam Deck has a great price, but you're gonna need more storage |url=https://www.polygon.com/22579004/steam-deck-storage-space-big-games-indie-titles |access-date=July 15, 2021 |website=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]}} Remote Play also allows the Steam Deck to be used as a controller for a game running on a computer, providing additional control options beyond traditional keyboard and mouse or common controller systems. The Steam software on the Deck also supports suspending a game in progress, a feature considered by Valve to be core to the Deck.{{Cite web |last=Marks |first=Tom |date=July 19, 2021 |title=Steam Deck: How SteamOS Bridges the Gap Between Console and PC |url=https://www.ign.com/articles/steam-deck-os-ui-system-software-bridges-the-gap-between-console-and-pc |access-date=July 19, 2021 |website=[[IGN]]}} Otherwise, games that do not take advantage of the Steam Deck API have the handheld's controller input automatically converted for them. For example, the touch-sensitive controllers on the Deck translate input appropriately for games that typically rely on [[keyboard and mouse]] controls. Valve added to Steam's current approach to cloud saving with the introduction of Dynamic Cloud Sync in January 2022. Prior cloud functionality only synchronized game saves after the user has exited a game; developers can enable Dynamic Cloud Sync to use cloud saving while the game is running, making this feature more amenable for portable use on the Steam Deck.{{Cite web |last=Mackovich |first=Sam |date=January 24, 2022 |title=Steam Deck will get the trippiest cloud-save functionality we've ever seen |url=https://arstechnica.com/gaming/2022/01/valve-updates-steams-cloud-save-system-to-make-steam-deck-more-intriguing/ |access-date=January 24, 2022 |website=[[Ars Technica]]}} Users download games onto the Steam Deck to store on either the internal storage or SD card, each storage device treated as a separate Steam Library for games. This allows SD cards with different Steam Libraries to be swapped in and out. Valve is exploring the ability to pre-load games on an SD card outside of the Deck, such as through a personal computer.{{Cite web |last=Jimenez |first=Jorge |date=July 23, 2021 |title=Valve explains how removable Steam Libraries will work on Steam Deck |url=https://www.pcgamer.com/valve-explains-how-removable-steam-libraries-will-work-on-steam-deck/ |access-date=July 23, 2021 |website=[[PC Gamer]]}} The ability to download games onto the Steam Deck from a local network Steam installation was added in February 2023.{{Cite web |last=Bonifacic |first=Igor |date=February 18, 2023 |title=Steam now allows you to copy games to Steam Deck and other PCs over a local network |url=https://www.engadget.com/steam-now-allows-you-to-copy-games-to-steam-deck-and-other-pcs-over-a-local-network-174444502.html?src=rss |access-date=February 18, 2023 |website=[[Engadget]]}} While the Deck was designed for playing games on the [[Steam (service)|Steam]] storefront, desktop mode allows for installation of third-party storefronts like [[Epic Games Store]], [[Ubisoft Connect]], or [[Origin (service)|Origin]].{{Cite web |last=Gartenberg |first=Chaim |date=July 15, 2021 |title=How does Valve's Steam Deck compare to the Nintendo Switch, Xbox Series X, and PlayStation 5? |url=https://www.theverge.com/2021/7/15/22578917/valve-steam-deck-nintendo-switch-xbox-series-x-ps5-spec-comparison |access-date=July 16, 2021 |website=[[The Verge]]}}{{Cite web |last=Dawe |first=Liam |date=2022-02-25 |title=Steam Deck desktop mode plus other stores — Epic Games Store |url=https://www.gamingonlinux.com/2022/02/steam-deck-desktop-mode-plus-other-stores-like-the-epic-games-store/ |access-date=2022-03-04 |website=GamingOnLinux |language=en}} It is possible to replace SteamOS with a different operating system entirely or set up [[multi-booting]].{{Cite web |last=Geblick |first=Jordan |date=September 22, 2021 |title=Valve answers all your burning Steam Deck questions in new FAQ |url=https://www.gamesradar.com/valve-answers-all-your-burning-steam-deck-questions-in-new-faq/ |access-date=September 22, 2021 |website=[[GamesRadar]]}} It is also possible to use the built-in browser for [[Xbox Cloud Gaming]], allowing those with [[Xbox Game Pass]] subscriptions access to that catalogue of games.{{Cite web |last=Robinson |first=Andy |date=August 14, 2021 |title=Phil Spencer has been testing Steam Deck and says Xbox games 'work well' |url=https://www.videogameschronicle.com/news/phil-spencer-has-been-testing-steam-deck-and-says-xbox-games-work-well/ |access-date=August 14, 2021 |website=[[Video Games Chronicle]]}} Newell stated that Valve would support Microsoft in bringing [[Xbox Game Pass]] to Steam and Steam Deck if they want that route.{{Cite web |last=Fenlon |first=Wes |date=February 25, 2022 |title=Valve has no plans for a 'Steam Pass,' but would help Microsoft put Game Pass on Steam |url=https://www.pcgamer.com/valve-has-no-plans-for-a-steam-pass-but-would-help-microsoft-put-game-pass-on-steam/ |access-date=February 25, 2022 |website=[[PC Gamer]]}} As part of the Steam Deck's launch, Valve released ''[[Aperture Desk Job]]'', a spinoff game in the ''[[Portal (series)|Portal]]'' series, for free on March 1, 2022, available to all Windows and Linux/SteamOS users. The game is designed to demonstrate the various features of the Steam Deck, though is still playable with a controller for other systems.{{Cite web |last=Hollister |first=Sean |date=February 25, 2022 |title=Valve made a bite-sized new Portal game for the Steam Deck |url=https://www.theverge.com/2022/2/25/22951072/valve-portal-steam-deck-aperture-desk-job |access-date=February 25, 2022 |website=[[The Verge]]}} To assist in developing and testing software for the Steam Deck, Valve released SteamOS Devkit Client and Server under [[open-source license]]s.{{Cite web |last=Dawe |first=Liam |date=2022-03-04 |title=Valve open sources SteamOS Devkit Client for Steam Deck |url=https://www.gamingonlinux.com/2022/03/valve-open-sources-steamos-devkit-client-for-steam-deck/ |access-date=2022-03-06 |website=GamingOnLinux |language=en}} Drivers for [[Windows]] are provided by Valve and AMD, but Valve does not provide support for them.{{Cite web |last=Dawe |first=Liam |date=2022-03-10 |title=Windows drivers roll out for Steam Deck but Valve won't support it |url=https://www.gamingonlinux.com/2022/03/windows-drivers-roll-out-for-steam-deck-but-valve-wont-support-it/ |access-date=2022-03-11 |website=GamingOnLinux |language=en}} ==Reception== The initial reaction to the announcement of the Steam Deck was positive. [[Epic Games]]' [[Tim Sweeney (game developer)|Tim Sweeney]] and [[Xbox Game Studios]]' [[Phil Spencer (business executive)|Phil Spencer]] complimented Valve on the Steam Deck, with Sweeney calling it an "amazing move by Valve!"{{Cite web |last=Chalk |first=Andy |date=July 15, 2021 |title=Tim Sweeney: Steam Deck is 'an amazing move by Valve' |url=https://www.pcgamer.com/uk/tim-sweeney-steam-deck-is-an-amazing-move-by-valve/ |access-date=July 16, 2021 |website=[[PC Gamer]]}} Spencer congratulated Valve "on getting so many of us excited to be able to take our games with us wherever we decide to play".{{Cite web |last=Watts |first=Steve |date=July 16, 2021 |title=Microsoft 'Always Excited' About Things Like Steam Deck, But No Game Pass Commitment Yet |url=https://www.gamespot.com/articles/microsoft-always-excited-about-things-like-steam-deck-but-no-game-pass-commitment-yet/1100-6494040/ |access-date=July 16, 2021 |website=[[GameSpot]]}} Many outlets compared the unit to that of the [[Nintendo Switch]], generally recognized as the first true hybrid video game console. Valve stated that they did not really consider the Switch in designing the Deck, as they "tried to make all the decisions really in Steam Deck that targeted that audience and that served the customers that were already having a good time interacting with the games that are on that platform, on our platform", and that by happenstance, came out with a device that was similar in function to the Switch.{{Cite web |last=Bailey |first=Kat |date=July 23, 2021 |title=Steam Deck: Valve Says It Never Really Compared Its Handheld to Switch |url=https://www.ign.com/articles/steam-deck-switch-comparison-gabe-newell-valve |access-date=July 23, 2021 |website=[[IGN]]}} ''[[The Verge]]'' stated that generally, the Steam Deck was a more powerful machine compared to the Switch, but that power came with a tradeoff in battery life which was greater with the Switch. Further, ''The Verge'' recognized that the specifications of the Deck were more comparable to the power of the consoles of the [[eighth generation of video game consoles|eighth generation]] like the [[Xbox One]] and [[PlayStation 4]], though using more recent [[Microarchitecture|compute/micro-]] and [[Graphics processing unit|graphics]] architectures than that which powered those older systems. ''[[Kotaku]]'' stated that while the Deck and Switch may be similar in concept, the two were not competing devices due to their target demographics, with the Switch aimed more at a broad audience machine, while the Deck was geared towards more "hardcore" gamers.{{Cite web |last=Hernandez |first=Patricia |date=July 16, 2021 |title=The Steam Deck Isn't Competing With The Nintendo Switch |url=https://kotaku.com/the-steam-deck-isnt-competing-with-the-nintendo-switch-1847304468 |access-date=July 16, 2021 |website=[[Kotaku]]}} ''[[Digital Foundry]]'' noted that while the Deck's hardware may be more powerful, non-Linux developers are not necessarily able to get low-level access to the CPU/GPU as developers working on the Switch due to the Proton emulation layer.{{Cite web |last=Leadbetter |first=Richard |date=July 20, 2021 |title=Spec Analysis: Steam Deck - can it really handle triple-A PC gaming? |url=https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/digitalfoundry-2021-valve-steam-deck-spec-analysis |access-date=July 20, 2021 |website=[[Eurogamer]]}} One of the main criticisms of the Steam Deck highlighted by multiple reviewers has been its battery life. Matt Hanson writing for ''[[TechRadar]]'' stated, "Less welcome is the fact that the battery life of the Steam Deck is pretty poor, with it just about managing one and a half hours while playing ''[[God of War (2018 video game)|God of War]]''" and that "Unfortunately during our time with the Steam Deck, battery life is an issue." He expanded by saying "That’s going to upset a lot of people who may have been planning on using the Steam Deck for long flights, for example" and that "it certainly makes this portable gaming system feel less… well, portable."{{Cite web |last=Hanson |first=Matt |date=26 February 2022 |title=Steam Deck review |url=https://www.techradar.com/reviews/steam-deck |access-date=28 February 2022 |website=[[TechRadar]]}} Matt Miller writing for ''[[Game Informer]]'' said that "Battery life is a significant problem" and that the device's battery life was "Punishingly low".{{Cite magazine |last=Miller |first=Matt |date=25 February 2022 |title=The Steam Deck Review |url=https://www.gameinformer.com/hardware/2022/02/25/the-steam-deck-review |magazine=[[Game Informer]] |access-date=28 February 2022}} Steve Hogarty writing for ''[[The Independent]]'' said "The battery life is by far the Steam deck’s biggest weakness. The handheld PC chugs through juice like it’s going out of fashion, with some graphically demanding games draining a full charge in as little as two hours of playtime."{{Cite news |last=Hogarty |first=Steve |date=18 March 2022 |title=Steam deck review: Valve's handheld gaming PC is revolutionary |work=[[The Independent]] |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/extras/indybest/gadgets-tech/video-games-consoles/steam-deck-review-b2021379.html |url-status=live |url-access=subscription |access-date=28 February 2022 |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20220524/https://www.independent.co.uk/extras/indybest/gadgets-tech/video-games-consoles/steam-deck-review-b2021379.html |archive-date=May 24, 2022}} Seth G. Macy writing for [[IGN]] wrote in very similar terms, saying, "Beyond that limitation, the biggest, most deflating issue I’ve had has been battery life. It’s all over the place and probably the biggest reality check when it comes to realizing the dream of truly untethered PC gaming."{{Cite web |last=Macy |first=Seth G. |date=2022-02-25 |title=Steam Deck Review |url=https://www.ign.com/articles/steam-deck-review |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220225180124/https://www.ign.com/articles/steam-deck-review |archive-date=2022-02-25 |access-date=2023-05-18 |website=[[IGN]]}} In terms of resolving this problem, Richard Leadbetter writing for ''[[Eurogamer]]'' said they "can't help feel that elements like
